Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: They see a swimmer struggling near the middle of the pool and need to stay vigilant to respond quickly.
Story: My phone buzzed in the lifeguard chair, and I glanced down to see my best friend’s name flashing. I answered, whispering, “Hey, what’s up?” Her voice was shaky, barely holding together. “Can you talk? I just… I really need you right now.” She was crying, and I could hear the pain in every word. I wanted to be there for her, to listen and comfort her like I always did. But as I tried to focus on her, my eyes kept darting back to the pool. The late-night swim was busy, and I spotted a swimmer in the middle, their strokes growing uneven. My training screamed at me to watch every move, to be ready to jump in at any second. My friend’s sobs pulled at my heart, but the pool demanded my full attention. I gripped the phone tighter, torn between being the friend she needed and the lifeguard everyone depended on. My mind raced, caught between the desperate voice in my ear and the struggling swimmer in the water, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed from me at the same time.
